proverb: Àbàtà takété bí ẹni pé kò bá odò tan
translation: The marshy place keeps aloof as if it is unrelated to the river
wisdom: When the going gets tough, pretty few will stick with you: mentally prepare for this; everybody loves the winner, but when you lose, you are on your own.
scenarios: Tunde’s startup was thriving, and friends praised his success. When it hit trouble, most stopped calling. Tunde relied on his resilience, learning loyalty is rare in tough times.;Amaka was a star athlete, celebrated during wins. An injury sidelined her, and only family checked in. She braced for future challenges, knowing support often ties to success.;Chidi’s campaign had loud supporters when polls favored him. As his opponent gained, many left, leaving a loyal few. He valued those who stayed and prepared for betrayals.

proverb: Ilẹ̀ àánú Olúwa kì í ṣú
translation: God's mercy never runs out
wisdom: No impossibility with God: He cannot be contained or cornered; keep hope alive.
scenarios: Funmi lost her job and felt hopeless, struggling with rent. A stranger offered a freelance gig just as eviction loomed. She held onto hope, trusting solutions come unexpectedly.;Ade’s diagnosis was dire, with little optimism from doctors. A new treatment appeared, and he recovered. He kept praying, believing divine intervention changes situations.

proverb: Orúkọ tí a bá sọ ajá ẹni lọmọ aráyé ńbá ni í pèé
translation: Whatever name one calls one's dog, that is the name others will call it as well
wisdom: Speak positively: words objectify themselves; never describe yourself or what you do in negative terms.
scenarios: Kemi called her business “just a side hustle,” and clients treated it casually. Labeling it a “growing enterprise” made customers take her seriously, increasing orders. Her words shaped perceptions.;Jide joked about being “clumsy” at work, and colleagues distrusted him with projects. Describing himself as “careful” earned him more responsibility. Positive self-description changed his reputation.;Bola’s friends called her art “cute doodles,” and she adopted the term. Labeling it “professional illustrations” drew gallery interest. Her words influenced her talent’s value.

proverb: Kò sí bí àtùpà ṣe lè lágbára tó, kò lè ríran rí ìdí ara rẹ̀
translation: No matter how strong a lamp is, it cannot light up it's base
wisdom: No matter how strong anyone is, he or she will always need the input of others; no one is wholly self-sufficient, nor indeed can be.
scenarios: Emeka, a brilliant coder, struggled to market his app. A friend’s promotion help led to soaring downloads. He saw his skills needed others’ expertise.;Chioma ran her restaurant well but couldn’t fix plumbing alone. Hiring a professional saved her business. She learned even the capable need support.

proverb: Ẹni a fẹ́ la mọ̀, a ò mọ ẹni tó fẹ́'ni
translation: You do know who you love for sure, but you cannot be certain of who really loves you
wisdom: Be perceptive; things are often not as they appear.
scenarios: Yemi trusted her colleague’s flattery, thinking they were friends. The colleague sabotaged her for a promotion. Yemi grew cautious, seeing intentions aren’t always genuine.;Tolu lent money to a “loyal” friend who never repaid. A quiet acquaintance helped Tolu selflessly. She observed actions, not words, to discern loyalty.;Sade thought her partner’s gifts showed love, but he was dismissive in her struggles. A neighbor supported her quietly. She valued sincerity over superficial gestures.

proverb: A kì í dámọ̀nràn àti tà'kìtì lágbàlá ọ̀bọ, nítorí ọ̀bọ fúnra'ra rẹ̀, ọba òkìtì ni
translation: Never toy with the idea of somersaulting in the vicinity of a monkey: monkeys themselves, are experts at somersaulting
wisdom: Be modest; don't make a needless show of your ignorance.
scenarios: Dayo bragged about coding skills before a senior developer, then fumbled at the task. The developer corrected him, and Dayo felt embarrassed. He learned quietly that it's better to embrace humility instead of boasting.;Amara tried outshining a veteran chef with a flashy dish she barely practiced. Her dish failed, while the chef’s simple recipe won. She learnt to respect expertise and avoided showing off.

proverb: Àdàbà ò náání à ńkùn'gbẹ́; pápá ńjó ẹyẹ oko fò lọ
translation: The dove is unmoved by the bush being set on fire; once on fire, it simply flies away
wisdom: Be strategic; in every situation, always have an assured plan B: it engenders calm in the midst of a storm.
scenarios: Ngozi saved money while working a stable job, anticipating layoffs. When her company downsized, she started a side business calmly. Her backup plan kept her steady.;Femi learned multiple skills, knowing his industry was volatile. When his job slowed, he pivoted to consulting without panic. His expertise was his escape route.;Aisha had an exit strategy for her rentals. When her landlord raised rent, she moved to a prepared alternative. Her foresight kept her unruffled.

proverb: Bàtà orí àkìtàn náà re òde ìyàwó rí
translation: Those pair of shoes on the refuse dump was once worn to a wedding
wisdom: Change is inevitable: a season must need go and another must need come; nothing lasts forever.
scenarios: Kunle led a top company, but economic shifts closed it. Now in a modest job, he accepts success can fade. He focuses on adapting.;Lara’s trendy boutique was popular until tastes changed. Her shop closed, but she retrained as a stylist. She understood no glory is permanent.

proverb: Èéfín ni ìwà; kò ṣeé fi pamọ́
translation: Character is like smoke: it cannot be covered up
wisdom: We cannot pretend to be who we are not for very long.
scenarios: Chike posed as a generous donor to gain trust. His stinginess in private leaked, and people shunned him. His true nature couldn’t hide.;Ronke was polite at work but gossiped cruelly. Her exposed messages lost her colleagues’ trust. Her character revealed itself.;Obi claimed honesty in pitches, but clients found exaggerated claims. They canceled contracts, ruining his reputation. His dishonesty surfaced.

proverb: Ṣiṣẹ́ ṣiṣẹ́ ò gọ̀, ó fẹ́ jàre ìṣẹ́ ni; ẹni tó kọ̀ tí ò ṣiṣẹ́ fẹ́ yan ìṣẹ́ láàyò ni
translation: The diligent isn't stupid, he or she simply wants to defeat poverty; the person who refuses to work, really seeks to partner with poverty
wisdom: Diligence is a choice: choose right.
scenarios: Tobi worked extra hours to fund education, despite mockery. He graduated and got a good job, while peers struggled. His hard work paid off.;Ezinne built her tailoring business on weekends, despite exhaustion. Her dedication attracted clients, unlike idle peers. She chose diligence and prospered.

proverb: Ọgbọ́n ju agbára lọ
translation: Wisdom is better than strength
wisdom: Pursue wisdom.
scenarios: Segun, a strong laborer, earned little lifting loads. Learning a skilled trade doubled his income. Wisdom outshone strength.;Adaeze farmed with brute effort but had poor yields. Studying soil management boosted her crops with less work. Wisdom proved better.;Uche wrestled easily but lost a deal due to poor negotiation. A strategy course won future contracts. Wisdom was more powerful.

proverb: Òròmọadìyẹ ńbá àṣá ṣeré, ó rò pé ẹyẹ oko lásán ni
translation: The chick gullibly plays with the hawk believing it to be an ordinary bird
wisdom: Naivety can be risky, if not fatally costly.
scenarios: Kemi trusted an online “investor” promising quick returns. She lost savings when the scheme collapsed. She learned to verify trust.;Bayo shared his startup idea with a competitor, thinking it was casual. The competitor launched it first, ruining Bayo’s plans. He guarded ideas after.

proverb: Bí afọ́jú bá lóun yóò fọ́'ni lójú, ó yẹ ká fura, nítorí tí kò bá mú nǹkan lọ́wọ́, ó lè tẹ nǹkan mọ́lẹ̀
translation: If a blind man threatens to make you blind, be wary; if he has nothing in his hands, he may have something under his feet
wisdom: Don't be presumptuous; underestimate no one.
scenarios: Tunde dismissed a coworker’s project warning. The issue cost the team, as the coworker predicted. Tunde respected all input after.;Amaka ignored a vendor’s threat to disrupt her supply. The vendor rallied others, delaying deliveries. She saw even minor players matter.;Chidi laughed off a junior’s critique of his plan. The flaw she spotted tanked the campaign. He stopped underestimating others.

proverb: Èyí wù mí, ò wù ọ́, lọmọ ìyá méjì ṣe ńfẹ́ ìyàwó ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀
translation: What appeals to me does not necessarily appeal to you is the reason two maternal brothers have different wives
wisdom: Different strokes for different folks; people are entitled to their choices: live and let live.
scenarios: Funmi loved spicy food, but Ada preferred mild. They stopped arguing and enjoyed separate dishes. Accepting differences strengthened them.;Jide wanted a corporate job, while Tolu chose entrepreneurship. Their parents supported both, avoiding conflict. They respected individual choices.

proverb: .Ẹni tó ńlé nǹkan níwájú, ńfi àwọn nǹkan míràn sẹ́hìn
translation: Whoever is pursuing something ahead, is actually leaving some other things behind. I
wisdom: There's always a price tag: we must let go of what is behind, if we want to lay hold of what is ahead.
scenarios: Ngozi moved abroad for a career, leaving friends behind. She missed them but gained success. She accepted the trade-off.;Femi quit his job to start a business, losing short-term security. His venture grew, but he lost family evenings. Progress required letting go.;Aisha focused on studies, skipping social events. She graduated with honors but missed fun. Her goal demanded sacrifices.

proverb: Àmójúkúrò ni í mú ẹ̀mí ìfẹ́ gùn
translation: Willingness to overlook is what makes for an enduring loving relationship
wisdom: If it is wrong, love will not see it; tolerance is crucial.
scenarios: Tobi ignored his wife’s tardiness, valuing their bond. Their marriage stayed strong through patience. Tolerance kept love alive.;Ezinne overlooked her friend’s blunt comments, knowing her heart was good. Their friendship endured where others faltered. She chose love over criticism.

proverb: A kì í fi ẹ̀tẹ̀ sílẹ̀ pa làpálàpá
translation: Do not leave leprosy unattended while preoccupied with treating ringworm
wisdom: Think perceptively and strategically: don't lose sight of the forest for the trees: look at the bigger picture; things are often more than they seem.
scenarios: Kemi fixed minor website bugs but ignored a security flaw. A hack cost her company, teaching her to prioritize critical issues. She saw the bigger picture.;Jide perfected his car’s paint but ignored faulty brakes. A near-accident made him reassess. He addressed root problems first.;Bola obsessed over party decor but neglected guests’ dietary needs. Complaints overshadowed the event. She planned broadly after.

proverb: Bí inú bá bí baba tó bá gbé ọmọ ẹ̀ jù sí inú èèrùn, bí inú ẹ̀ bá rọ̀, inú èèrùn lè má rọ̀
translation: If a father gets so angry as to throw his child into a raid of army ants, by the time he calms down, the ants may not be
wisdom: Don't be hasty in anger: calm down; avoid rashness.
scenarios: Chidi yelled at his employee over a mistake, nearly firing him. After cooling off, the employee had resigned. He paused before reacting after.;Amaka deleted her friend’s contact in anger. By the time she calmed, the friend had moved on. She avoided rash decisions later.

proverb: Báa gún iyán, táa ro ọkà fún kòfẹ́kògbà, kò ní fẹ́, kò ní gbà, náà ni
translation: Even if you pound yam and prepare yam flour meal for a contentious person, he or she will yet remain contentious
wisdom: Be forward-looking, be positive; do your best and keep moving.
scenarios: Tolu pleased a difficult client with extra work, but they criticized him. He delivered quality and moved on. He stayed positive.;Sade cooked for her grumpy neighbor, who complained. She stayed kind but focused on her goals. Positivity kept her unshaken.;Obi exceeded a picky boss’s expectations, yet faced complaints. He did his best and sought better opportunities. He ignored negativity.

proverb: Bó ti wù kí ojú kan tóbi tó, ojú méjì sàn ju ojú kan lọ
translation: No matter how big an eye is, two eyes are better than one
wisdom: Team effort is superior.
scenarios: Emeka built a house alone but struggled with flaws. A team of builders finished it faster and better. Collaboration was key.;Chioma planned a community event solo, but it was chaotic. A team’s help made it smooth next time. Group effort beat solo work.

proverb: A kì í sọ òkò sí ẹyẹ tó ńwá ọ̀nà àti fò
translation: Do not throw stones at a bird that seeks to fly away
wisdom: Act in wisdom: do not pre-empt or worsen an already deplorable situation.
scenarios: Yemi’s employee was quitting due to stress, and she avoided criticism. Her kind exit interview led to a referral. She chose wisdom.;Tolu saw his friend struggling and didn’t press for a loan repayment. His patience preserved their bond. He avoided escalating tensions.;Sade gave her upset sister space instead of pushing her. Her sister opened up later. She acted wisely to avoid worsening things.

proverb: Ikú fẹ́ pa alápatà ó ńkígbe; ọmọ ẹranko tó ti dá lóró ńkọ́?
translation: Death stalks the butcher and he screams; what about the animals he's butchered?
wisdom: Exact from no one what you are unwilling to impose on yourself; be fair and considerate.
scenarios: Kemi demanded perfection from her team but overlooked her errors. They called her out, and she felt embarrassed. She held herself to the same standard.;Jide criticized his sibling for laziness but ignored his procrastination. His sibling pointed out hypocrisy, and Jide changed. He practiced fairness.

proverb: Tí ìṣẹ́ ò bá jẹ́ ká sọ òdodo, àìṣòdodo kò ní jẹ́ ká bọ́ lọ́wọ́ ìṣẹ́
translation: If fear of poverty makes us lie, lying will keep us entrenched in poverty, as well
wisdom: Honesty pays; dishonest lifestyle does exact hefty fees, at the end.
scenarios: Tobi exaggerated his resume but couldn’t deliver. He was fired, losing more than he gained. He built skills honestly after.;Ezinne sold fake products for quick cash, but bad reviews collapsed her business. She rebuilt with integrity. Honesty proved valuable.;Ade hid a car’s faults to sell it, but the buyer sued. Legal fees drained him. He chose transparency thereafter.

proverb: Ojú tí kò rí yànnà yánná iná, yẹ̀rẹ̀ yẹrẹ oòrùn, kì í rí yìndìn yindin idẹ
translation: A pair of eyes that won't endure the fiery flames of fire, the searing glare of the sun, can't hope to enjoy the glittering beauty of brass
wisdom: No pain, no gain; no guts, no glory.
scenarios: Funmi avoided studying late but wanted high grades. She failed and learned effort was key. She worked hard for success.;Jide skipped training, fearing injury, but dreamed of winning races. He lost and practiced rigorously. Sacrifice brought rewards.

proverb: Ọ̀nà kan ò wọ ọjà
translation: Not just one route leads to the market
wisdom: Alternative approaches exist; there are many ways to achieve an end; don't be fixated on one.
scenarios: Ngozi’s job application failed, but an internship led to a better role. Multiple paths brought success. She stayed flexible.;Femi’s loan was denied, so he crowdfunded his startup. The campaign succeeded, showing other routes. He embraced alternatives.;Aisha’s college rejection led to a vocational program. She built a thriving career. Different paths worked.

proverb: Ẹni tó bá ní kí ọ̀rẹ́ òun má jọba ni kò ní lọ̀rẹ́ ọba
translation: Whoever blocks his friend from becoming a king won't have a king as a friend.,
wisdom: Foster goodness: those plotting evil for others often share in the evil results; we reap whatever we sow.
scenarios: Tolu sabotaged his colleague’s promotion out of jealousy. The colleague left, cutting ties. Tolu lost a connection.;Sade discouraged her friend’s business, hoping to outshine her. The friend succeeded and distanced herself. Harming others backfired.

proverb: Ẹni tí a  ńbá ná'jà la ńwò a kì í wo ariwo ọjà
translation: Wẹ should be focused on the person we are trading with and not the din and bustle in the market
wisdom: Be focused; shun distractions.
scenarios: Emeka lost a client by checking his phone during a meeting. He missed details and seemed uninterested. He stayed present after.;Chioma got distracted by social media while studying and failed. Phone-free study hours improved her grades. Focus brought results.;Obi ignored a customer, drawn to a market argument. The customer left, costing a sale. He prioritized clients.

proverb: Etí mẹ́ta ò yẹ orí; èèyàn mẹ́ta ò lè dúró ní méjì-méjì
translation: Three ears do not suit the head; three people cannot stand in groups of twos
wisdom: There is always a right and wrong way to do anything: focus on the right way.
scenarios: Kemi mixed incompatible chemicals, causing a reaction. Following protocol gave accurate results. She stuck to proper methods.;Jide rushed a project with shortcuts, delivering poor work. Redoing it correctly earned praise. He prioritized the right approach.

proverb: A kì í mọ iyì wúrà tí kò bá sọnù
translation: A piece of gold (ornament) is seldom appreciated until it gets lost
wisdom: We seldom appreciate what we have, until we lose it; the available is easily taken for granted.
scenarios: Tobi ignored his mother’s advice, thinking it common. After her passing, he craved her wisdom. He regretted not valuing her.;Amaka complained about her job, overlooking benefits. When laid off, she missed stability. She appreciated what she had.;Chidi took his car’s reliability for granted. A breakdown made him realize its value. He maintained it better.

proverb: Àìdúpẹ́ oore àná a máa mú oore sú'ni í ṣe
translation: Lack of gratitude for yesterday's kindness does make future acts of kindness tiresome
wisdom: Attitude of gratitude is it; take nothing for granted: whatever is taken for granted diminishes; whatever is appreciated increases.
scenarios: Funmi never thanked her mentor, so he stopped helping. She apologized, and he resumed. Gratitude restored opportunity.;Jide accepted family support without thanks, and they felt unvalued. Expressing gratitude made them give willingly. Gratitude worked.

proverb: Oò ṣá igi lọ́gbẹ́, oò ta ògùrọ̀ lọfà, o dé ìdí ọ̀pẹ, o ńgbẹ́nu s'ókè; ṣé ọ̀fẹ́ ló máa ńro ni?
translation: You neither hacked a palm nor stabbed a raffia, yet you opened up your mouth under a palm for wine; does it drip freely?
wisdom: No free lunch; take responsibility; pay the price.
scenarios: Ngozi expected free supplies without networking. She invested in relationships and earned discounts. Effort brought rewards.;Femi demanded a promotion without work but was denied. Taking on tasks earned it later. Nothing comes without cost.;Aisha wanted free tutoring but didn’t study. Paying for classes and working hard passed exams. Success required effort.

proverb: Àgbẹ̀ tó jẹun yó tó fọ́ akèrègbè, ti gbàgbé pé ọjọ́ òǹgbẹ ṣì ńbọ̀
translation: The farmer who ate, had his fill, and broke the water gourd has forgotten that days of thirst are ahead
wisdom: Be strategic: think ahead; never slam the door on your way out: you may need it opened in future.
scenarios: Tunde quit his job rudely, burning bridges. He needed a reference but was refused. He exited gracefully after.;Adaeze sold her tools, assuming she’d never farm. Rising prices made her regret it. She planned better.

proverb: Òjò tó rọ̀ sí ewúro, náà ló rọ̀ sí ìrèké
translation: The same rain that fell on the bitter-leaf, fell on the sugarcane (yet bitter-leaf is bitter while sugarcane remains sweet.)
wisdom: Our reactions tell of who we really are deep down; bitter or vengeful responses are by choice.
scenarios: Emeka and Chioma lost contracts but reacted differently. Emeka found new clients, while Chioma grew bitter. Choices showed their selves.;Obi faced criticism but responded kindly, earning respect. His colleague lashed out, losing allies. Reactions revealed character.

proverb: Adániwáyè ò gbàgbé ẹnìkan; àìmàsìkò ló ńdààmú ẹ̀dá
translation: God has not forgotten anyone; ignorance of divine timing is what makes us fret
wisdom: Keep hope alive; hang on there: the best is yet to come.
scenarios: Yemi waited years for a child, feeling abandoned. She adopted, then conceived, renewing faith. She trusted divine timing.;Tolu’s business struggled, but he prayed. A deal came before he gave up. He held onto hope.;Sade’s scholarship was delayed, causing worry. It arrived in time for school. She stayed hopeful.

proverb: Bí a kò bá dẹ́kun ìgbìyànjú, bópẹ́ bóyá akitiyan á dópin lọ́jọ́ kan
translation: If one won't give up trying, one's hustling will one day come to an end
wisdom: Never give up, never quit; if we won't quit, we will win eventually.
scenarios: Kemi failed her driving test but kept practicing. She passed on her fifth attempt. She never quit.;Jide’s startup pitches were rejected, but he refined his plan. An investor backed him. Persistence paid off.

proverb: Ohun tí a bá bò, ló ńníyì
translation: Whatever is covered up (or not easily accessible) is what is respected and honoured
wisdom: Familiarity breeds contempt: whatever is easily available typically loses value and worth.
scenarios: Tobi shared designs freely, and clients undervalued them. Limiting access grew demand. Scarcity increased worth.;Amaka always answered calls instantly, so friends took her lightly. Setting boundaries earned respect. Rarity added value.;Chidi gave free advice, and people ignored it. Charging made clients listen. Limited access raised credibility.

proverb: Apẹ́kótójẹun kò ní jẹ bàjẹ́
translation: The one who tarries to eat won't necessarily eat a lousy meal
wisdom: Delay is not necessarily denial; often delays imply the perfection of the object hoped for; keep hope alive: it is not over yet.
scenarios: Funmi waited years for a good partner, rejecting rushed proposals. She met a compatible spouse later. Patience brought quality.;Jide’s loan took months but came with better terms. He expanded his shop successfully. Delay refined opportunity.

proverb: Tó bá kù díẹ̀ kí ọmọ olóore jìn sí kòtò, mànàmáná á ṣiṣẹ́ ìmọ́lẹ̀ fún un
translation: Just before a kind person would stumble into a ditch (in darkness), the lightning would light up his or her path to save the day
wisdom: Kindness pays: it's good to be good; kind acts are never lost.
scenarios: Tobi helped a stranger fix a tire, expecting nothing. The stranger connected him to a job. Kindness came back.;Ezinne shared notes with struggling classmates. They helped her move later. Generosity was rewarded.;Ade donated to charities quietly. When his shop burned, the community rebuilt it. Good deeds returned.

proverb: A kì í fura sí ẹni tí a ńbá rìn; ẹni tí a bá ńfura sí, a kì í bá irú wọn rìn
translation: Do not be suspicious of those you associate with; those you'd be suspicious of, should not be your close associates
wisdom: Build trust; avoid paranoia; be positive; be forward-looking.
scenarios: Yemi doubted her teammate, straining their project. Trusting and communicating improved work. Positivity strengthened bonds.;Tolu avoided a shady partner he distrusted. Honest colleagues led to a thriving venture. Trust guided choices.

proverb: Ká dúpẹ́ lọ́wọ́ ọrùn tó gbé orí dúró; ọ̀pọ̀ ẹran ló sún mọ́ orí tí ò ṣe nǹkankan
translation: Wẹ ought to be thankful to the neck for supporting the head; many tissues are close to it, yet do nothing
wisdom: Be thankful, even for small favours.
scenarios: Emeka thanked his driver for small errands. The driver went extra miles in a crisis. Gratitude built loyalty.;Chioma appreciated her neighbor’s childcare help. The neighbor offered more when needed. Thanks fostered kindness.;Obi acknowledged his intern’s contributions. The intern shared a tip, saving his project. Small thanks yielded returns.

proverb: Àgbẹ̀ tí kòkó ẹ̀ yè, kì í ṣe mímọ̀ ọ́ ṣe ẹ̀, bíkòṣe Elédùà
translation: A farmer with a thriving cocoa farm owes this not to his or her effort, but to God
wisdom: There is no self-made person: we are all God-made:; we must remain small in our very own eyes; we must be ever so modest.
scenarios: Tunde boasted about his business, ignoring luck and mentors. A loss humbled him, crediting divine help. Humility grounded him.;Kemi attributed her promotion to work alone. A colleague reminded her of divine timing. She stayed modest.

proverb: À ti gbé ìyàwó ò tóó pọ́n; owó ọbẹ̀ ló ṣòro
translation: Getting married is not an issue; meeting the marriage responsibility is the tough nut
wisdom: Look before you leap; think well before you act; it's easy to start some things, but tough to sustain it.
scenarios: Ngozi rushed into marriage, charmed by romance. Financial struggles tested her unpreparedness. She wished she’d planned.;Femi opened a shop without a budget, excited by sales. Maintaining stock overwhelmed him. He learned long-term thinking.;Aisha adopted a pet impulsively, loving its cuteness. Care costs shocked her. She researched commitments after.

proverb: Jẹ́ kí ńfìdí hẹẹ́, ni àlejò fi ńti onílé sóde
translation: Let me just hang in here, is how the guest takes over the house from the host
wisdom: Think well about that inch you want to give, it may well become a mile: be perceptive, be circumspect.
scenarios: Tolu let a friend crash temporarily, but they overstayed. Setting boundaries was hard, losing privacy. He was cautious after.;Amaka shared work resources, and a colleague monopolized them. Reclaiming control disrupted workflow. She limited access early.

proverb: Ọwọ́ ọlọ́wọ́ ò lè yó ẹnu ẹlẹ́nu
translation: Never expect the hands of someone else to feed you to satisfaction
wisdom: Depend less, possibly not at all, on anyone: go catch your own fish.
scenarios: Emeka relied on his uncle’s funds but felt stuck. He learned a trade and gained independence. Self-reliance brought pride.;Chioma lived off friends’ generosity but wanted freedom. Her small business earned income. Autonomy felt great.;Obi borrowed constantly, straining ties. He saved and budgeted, breaking the cycle. Independence empowered him.

proverb: Bí ẹ̀dá bá fẹ́ gba àwìn ẹ̀bà, ni wọ́n máa ńṣe ojú àánú; tí wọ́n bá yó tán, wọ́n á di ọkọ olúwa wọn
translation: People present a facade of humility when seeking favour, but easily lord it over their benefactors, once satisfied
wisdom: Be perceptive; things are often not as they appear.
scenarios: Yemi’s friend begged for a loan, acting humble. After getting it, he ignored her calls. She watched for hidden motives.;Tolu hired a charming intern who flattered him. Once trained, the intern took credit for work. He grew wary of fake humility.

proverb: Ọlọ́run ò fẹ́ irọ́; ọmọ èyàn ò fẹ́ òdodo; bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ̀rọ̀ ò pé mẹ́ta
translation: God hates lies; man hates truths; yet there is no third option in a discourse
wisdom: It is better to always stick with the truth, even when there are no easy options.
scenarios: Kemi lied about a project delay to avoid blame. The truth surfaced, damaging credibility. She chose honesty after.;Jide hid a product flaw, fearing backlash. Complaints hurt his brand. Truth became his policy.;Bola denied a mistake to save face. The error cost her team, losing trust. She embraced truth.

proverb: Kì í ṣe gbogbo ajá tó bá ńgbó'ni lọ́jà, la ńdá lóhùn
translation: It's not all the dogs that bark at one at the marketplace that one responds to
wisdom: Stay focused: ignore distractions; not all issues should get our attention.
scenarios: Tunde ignored trolls criticizing his blog. He focused on content, growing his audience. Distractions didn’t derail him.;Amaka avoided office gossip and worked diligently. Her productivity earned a promotion. She stayed focused.

proverb: Ọba tí kì í fẹ́ gba ìmọ̀ràn, irú wọn kì í pẹ́ fi ẹsẹ̀ kọ
translation: Any king who despises counsels, hardly takes long before stumbling
wisdom: It's smart to be open to and treasure good counsels: those who spurn them needlessly expose themselves to avoidable errors.
scenarios: Emeka ignored his team’s budget warnings and overspent. The project failed, teaching him to listen. Counsel saved efforts.;Chioma dismissed her mentor’s marketing advice, and her campaign flopped. Guidance led to success later. She valued advice.;Obi rejected workers’ safety tips, causing an accident. He embraced input later, avoiding repeats. Counsel was key.

proverb: Ọmọ aráyé ńp'àtẹ́wọ́ fún yànmùyánmú, inú ẹ̀ ńdùn; kò mọ̀ pé òun ńfi ikú ṣeré ni
translation: People clap for mosquito and it rejoices, oblivious that it is toying with death
wisdom: Be perceptive: not all positive gestures are noble.
scenarios: Yemi joined a flashy investment group due to praise. It was a scam, costing money. She questioned flattery.;Tolu followed a crowd cheering a risky trend and regretted it. Applause masked danger. He grew perceptive.

proverb: A kì í wo ìyẹ́ adìyẹ nílẹ̀, kí a wá fi ìrù àkèekèé rin etí
translation: No one has a hen's feather within reach and opt to scratch his or her inner ear with a scorpion's stinger
wisdom: Avoid needless exposures to high risks.
scenarios: Kemi used a shady lender instead of her bank, losing funds. She had safer options but ignored them. She avoided risky shortcuts.;Jide invested all savings in one stock, ignoring diversification. The stock crashed, and he regretted it. He chose safer strategies.;Bola drove a faulty car to save costs, risking an accident. A breakdown forced repairs. She prioritized safety.

proverb: Bí inú bá bí baba tó bá gbé ọmọ rẹ̀ jù sí inú eèrùn, bí inú rẹ̀ bá rọ̀, inú eèrùn lè má rọ̀
translation: If a father gets so angry as to throw his child into a raid of army ants, by the time he calms down, the ants may not be
wisdom: Avoid rashness; be wary of taking crucial decisions when angry.
scenarios: Chidi fired his assistant in a rage over a minor error. By the time he calmed down, she had joined a rival firm, taking clients. He learned to pause before acting in anger.;Amaka yelled at her son for spilling juice, grounding him harshly. Later, she regretted it, but he was hurt, teaching her to avoid rash decisions.;Tolu banned a friend from his shop after a heated argument. When calm, he realized the loss, vowing to think twice in anger.

proverb: A kì í bá ara ẹni tan kí á fa ara ẹni n'ítan ya
translation: To be related to someone is no excuse to be unconscionably dependent on him or her
wisdom: Good to take personal responsibility; never abuse your privileges: there is a limit to everything.
scenarios: Funmi relied on her cousin’s funds for rent, straining their bond. Her cousin cut her off, forcing Funmi to find a job. She learned not to abuse family ties.;Jide borrowed tools from his brother endlessly, never replacing them. His brother stopped lending, teaching Jide to take responsibility.;Sade lived with her aunt, neglecting chores. When asked to leave, she saw the limit of her privilege.

proverb: Tí ògiri ò bá la'nu, aláǹgbá ò lè r'áyè wọ̀ ọ́
translation: If there are no crevices in the wall, the lizard cannot penetrate into the wall
wisdom: Actions beckon, and quite often, compel reactions; to stop an effect, eliminate the action causing it.
scenarios: Kemi ignored a small leak in her shop, attracting pests. The damage grew until she fixed it, costing more. Addressing flaws early stopped worse issues.;Tolu left his gate unlocked, inviting thieves. After a burglary, he secured it, seeing actions cause reactions.;Chidi gossiped, sparking rumors about him. He stopped, ending the cycle of backlash.

proverb: Màlúù tí ò n'írù, Ọlọ́run ni í lé eṣinṣin fún un
translation: It's God that fends off flies for a cow that has no tail
wisdom: God helps those who can't help themselves; whatever is impossible to man, is possible with God.
scenarios: Emeka prayed for help when his car broke down, stranded. A stranger towed him home, reinforcing his faith. God aided where he couldn’t manage.;Aisha lost her job and trusted God for provision. A new opportunity came, proving divine help for the helpless.;Sade’s sick child recovered after prayers. Her trust in God’s power grew stronger.

proverb: Kí a tó dé ibi tí à ńlọ, a máa ńkọ́kọ́ dé ibi tí a kò fẹ́
translation: Before getting to our destination, we may have to get to where we'd rather not be
wisdom: Be focused, be strategic: always look ahead; don't lose the forest for the trees.
scenarios: Yemi took a low-paying job to survive, hating it. It led to a dream role, showing detours have purpose. Focusing ahead kept him motivated.;Kemi endured a tough internship, feeling stuck. It opened doors to a major firm, teaching her to look beyond the moment.;Tolu worked nights to fund school, despite exhaustion. His degree landed a top job, proving strategic focus pays.

proverb: Ẹni tí ò fẹ́ wọ àkísà, kì í bá ajá ṣe eré e géle
translation: Don't play rough with a dog, if you don't want to end up in tatters
wisdom: Look before you leap; think before you act: actions come with consequences.
scenarios: Chidi partied with risky friends, ruining his suit. Their rough games cost him, teaching him to think before acting. He chose calmer company.;Amaka wrestled with her dog, tearing her dress. She avoided rough play after, seeing actions have consequences.;Sade joined a prank group, getting hurt. She left, learning to assess risks first.

proverb: Odò tó ńṣàn kì í b'ojú w'ẹ̀hìn
translation: A flowing stream never looks (or flows) backward
wisdom: Be forward-looking; be focused: no one drives forward with eyes on the rearview mirror.
scenarios: Tolu dwelled on past business failures, stalling growth. He set new goals, doubling sales. Forward focus drove success.;Kemi obsessed over a lost deal, missing new ones. She moved on, signing bigger clients.;Chidi kept regretting a breakup, slowing his career. He focused ahead, thriving in new ventures.

proverb: Àbá làá kó dànù; ẹnìkan kì í kó aláàbá dànù
translation: You may only discard a suggestion, but not the one who made it
wisdom: A case against ad hominem; question and attack ideas not personalities.
scenarios: Funmi criticized her colleague’s bad idea, not her character. Their bond stayed strong, and they improved the plan. Attacking ideas, not people, worked.;Jide rejected his friend’s risky proposal but kept their tie. They collaborated later, proving ideas can be questioned without harm.;Sade disliked her boss’s strategy but respected her. She suggested tweaks, earning trust.

proverb: Èyàn kì í mọ iyì ohun tó ní, à fi tó bá sọ ọ́ nù
translation: We seldom appreciate what we have, until we lose the thing
wisdom: Take nothing desired for granted: we lose, sometimes permanently, whatever we take for granted; treasure whatever you wish to keep.
scenarios: Tolu took his reliable bike for granted, neglecting it. It broke down, stranding him, and he valued it after repairs. Treasuring what he had saved loss.;Kemi ignored her old phone until it failed, losing contacts. She backed up her new one, learning to appreciate tools.;Aisha overlooked her mentor’s advice, missing opportunities. After losing her, she cherished guidance.

proverb: Omi kì í korò lẹ́nu láì ní ìdí
translation: Water does not just taste bitter in the mouth without a reason
wisdom: There is a reason for every seeming anomaly; there is not smoke without fire.
scenarios: Chidi’s coffee tasted bitter, revealing spoiled milk. He checked expiry dates after, seeing reasons behind issues. Investigating anomalies prevented waste.;Amaka’s car stalled, traced to bad fuel. She used trusted stations, knowing problems have causes.;Sade’s plant wilted, due to overwatering. She adjusted care, learning issues aren’t random.

proverb: Bí agbada ò bá gbóná, àgbàdo ò leè ta
translation: If the frying pan is not heated up, the corns cannot pop
wisdom: Good things do not always come easy; no pain, no gain.
scenarios: Tolu rushed his baking, serving raw bread. He heated the oven properly, perfecting his loaves. Effort brought results.;Kemi skipped workouts, expecting fitness. She trained hard, gaining strength, proving pain yields gain.;Chidi wrote code hastily, facing bugs. Diligent debugging fixed it, showing effort is key.

proverb: Bí èyàn bá dúró sínú oòrùn títí, bó pẹ́ bó yá, ibòji, á báa níbẹ̀
translation: If one tarries long in the sun, eventually, the shade will come (when the sun sets)
wisdom: Tough times cannot last forever; keep hope alive.
scenarios: Emeka endured a harsh job, hoping for relief. A promotion came, proving tough times pass. Hope sustained him.;Aisha’s shop struggled in a slump, but sales rebounded. She held on, seeing seasons change.;Tolu faced loan rejections, but one passed. Patience showed hard times end.

proverb: Òkun kì í hó ruru, kí á wà á ruru
translation: Never paddle wildly in a stormy sea
wisdom: Be patient; complex issues should be carefully and patiently handled.
scenarios: Kemi panicked during a project crisis, worsening it. She calmed down, solving it step-by-step. Patience handled complexity.;Jide rushed a repair, breaking his phone. Slow care fixed it later, teaching calm precision.;Sade argued in a dispute, escalating it. She listened calmly, resolving it peacefully.

proverb: Ìgbín ò lè sáré bí Ajá; ìyẹn ò ní kó máà de ibi tó ńlọ
translation: The snail cannot run as fast as the dog; that won't stop it from getting to wherever it's going
wisdom: We are all uniquely endowed, and complete enough to live out our lives; stay in your lane: envy no one.
scenarios: Funmi envied her friend’s fast career, rushing her own. She crashed but thrived at her pace. Staying in her lane worked.;Tolu copied his rival’s business, failing. He built his unique brand, succeeding by being himself.;Chidi chased others’ wealth, losing focus. His steady path brought stability.

proverb: Bó ti wù kí ojú kan tóbi tó, ojú méjì sàn ju ojú kan lọ
translation: No matter how big an eye is, two eyes are better than one
wisdom: Team spirit is it; together everyone achieves more; cooperate and collaborate more.
scenarios: Emeka planned a solo event, missing details. A team’s help made it flawless, proving collaboration wins. Teamwork outdid lone effort.;Aisha coded alone, hitting bugs. Colleagues’ input fixed it, showing two eyes beat one.;Tolu marketed solo, with weak results. A group campaign soared, valuing team spirit.

proverb: Ká mú ẹyin sí ọwọ́ ọ̀tún, ká mú ẹyìn sí ọwọ́ òsì, ká fí ẹ̀yìn rìn láti Ìsẹ́yìn dé Ìyìn Èkìtì, ẹni tí kò ní fi iṣẹ́ yin'ni kò ni fi yin’ni
translation: Even if one were to grab an egg with the right hand, a palm-nut with the left, and retro-walked from Iseyin (a town) to Iyin Ekiti, those who won't be grateful, still won't be
wisdom: You can't please everyone: do your very best and move on.
scenarios: Funmi overdid favors for a client, who stayed ungrateful. She did her best and moved on, accepting not all can be pleased.;Jide gifted his neighbor endlessly, but they complained. He focused on others, knowing some won’t value effort.;Sade taught kids for free, but parents grumbled. She helped elsewhere, unbothered by ingrates.

proverb: Ẹni tó ńbẹ̀rù àti ṣubú, àti dìde á nira fún un
translation: Whoever is scared of falling will find rising pretty tough
wisdom: Be bullish; take calculated risks; nothing ventured, nothing gained.
scenarios: Chidi feared pitching his startup, delaying it. He risked it, landing funds, proving boldness pays. Calculated risks brought gain.;Amaka avoided investing, scared of loss. She tried small stocks, earning profits, seeing risk’s value.;Tolu shunned public speaking, fearing failure. He spoke, gaining clients, embracing bold moves.

proverb: A kì í ṣe fáàrí ẹ̀ṣẹ́ dídì, si ọmọ adẹ́tẹ̀
translation: Don’t brag about fists in the presence of a leper
wisdom: Be considerate, courteous and tactful. Be sensitive and show empathy.
scenarios: Kemi bragged about her strength to a struggling friend. Her friend withdrew, hurt by her insensitivity. She showed empathy after.;Jide mocked a sick colleague’s weakness, losing trust. He apologized, learning tactful care.;Sade flaunted her skills to a novice, discouraging them. She mentored gently, building their confidence.

proverb: Èéfín ni ìwà; kò ṣeé fi pamọ́
translation: Character is like smoke; it cannot be covered up
wisdom: No one can pretend to be who he is not for long; ultimately, our character shows through.
scenarios: Tolu hid his gossip habit, but it spread, ruining ties. His true nature surfaced, costing friends. Character always shows.;Aisha faked kindness at work, but her rudeness leaked. Colleagues shunned her, proving pretense fails.;Chidi lied about his skills, but failures exposed him. His real self emerged, teaching honesty.

proverb: Ẹni bá ńsọ òkò sí adìyẹ igba, òkò ló máa sọ tí ilẹ̀ á fi ṣú
translation: Whoever is throwing stones at two hundred hens, will be at it until the evening
wisdom: Be focused; don't flock shoot; to focus on doing too many at once, is a recipe for doing none.
scenarios: Kemi chased multiple clients, delivering poorly. She focused on one, excelling, proving focus beats scatter. Prioritizing worked.;Jide juggled three jobs, burning out. He picked one, thriving, seeing less is more.;Tolu taught many subjects, confusing students. He specialized, improving results with focus.

proverb: Tí àdúrà bá gbà tán, apá aládúrà ò ní ká a
translation: When a prayer is answered, the person who prayed would be overwhelmed
wisdom: Prayers work; God's response can be so complete as to be overwhelming.
scenarios: Emeka prayed for a job, landing one beyond his dreams. The fit overwhelmed him, showing prayers work. Faith brought abundance.;Aisha sought healing through prayer, recovering fast. The miracle stunned her, proving divine answers.;Sade prayed for funds, receiving a grant. Its scale amazed her, reinforcing prayer’s power.

proverb: Gbogbo ọ̀rọ̀ ló lésì, ṣùgbọ́n kì í ṣe gbogbo ọ̀rọ̀ làá fèsì sí
translation: There is always an appropriate response to every statement, but it's not every statement that one responds to
wisdom: Be focused and ignore distractions; not all issues deserve one's attention.
scenarios: Chidi answered every critic online, losing time. He ignored noise, boosting his blog’s growth. Focus trumped distractions.;Kemi debated petty gossip, stalling work. She skipped it, finishing projects faster.;Tolu responded to all complaints, draining energy. He addressed key ones, saving effort.

proverb: Àgbẹ̀ tó roko tí kò gbin ọkà lóun dá ikún lóró; ikún kọ́ ló dá lóró, ara ẹ̀ ló dá lóró
translation: A farmer who ploughed his farm, but planted no corn claims he's hurting the ground squirrel; he hasn't hurt any squirrel, but himself
wisdom: Be positive, be forward-looking; vindictive actions can be self-limiting.
scenarios: Jide blamed his rival for a loss, hurting himself. His spite delayed recovery, teaching positivity. Forward focus rebuilt his brand.;Amaka sought revenge on a cheating client, losing focus. She moved on, gaining better deals.;Sade plotted against a rude neighbor, wasting time. She ignored them, thriving with positivity.

proverb: Bí èyàn ò bá rìn ní igbèrí irọ́, wọn kì í paá mọ́'ni
translation: If one is not within the vicinity of falsehoods, one cannot be falsely accused
wisdom: Personal integrity is crucial; quite often, it determines one's experience.
scenarios: Kemi stayed honest at work, avoiding false blame. Her integrity shielded her from rumors. Truth kept her clear.;Tolu refused to lie on a deal, dodging a scam. His honesty saved his funds.;Chidi admitted a mistake, escaping false accusations. Integrity protected his name.

proverb: Bí ọmọdé bá lóun ò mẹ̀wẹ̀, pé òun ò mòwè, àá sì já ẹ̀wẹ̀ sí ọwọ ọ̀tún, àá já òwè sí ọwọ òsì fún un ni
translation: If a youngster claims ignorance of the ẹ̀wẹ̀ and òwè leaves, one ought to pluck one on his (or her) right hand and the other on his left for him
wisdom: Assert real (or feigned) ignorance of personal responsibility gently, but firmly; don't encourage abdication of responsibility.
scenarios: Funmi let her son dodge chores, enabling laziness. She assigned tasks, building his duty. Firm guidance curbed irresponsibility.;Jide excused his staff’s delays, causing chaos. He set deadlines, improving output with accountability.;Aisha allowed her sibling to skip school, harming them. She enforced study, fostering growth.

proverb: Àgbàlagbà tó bá fẹ́ fọ inú akèrègbè mọ́ gbọ́dò ṣ'ọ̀rẹ́ ọmọdé, bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni ọmọdé tó bá fẹ́ mú nǹkan lórí pẹpẹ gbọdọ̀ sún mọ́ àgbàlagbà nítorí ọwọ́ ọmọdé ò tó pẹpẹ t'àgbàlagbà ò wọ akèrègbè
translation: An elderly person who wants to wash the inside of a gourd, clean, must befriend a child; so also a child who wants to retrieve something on a high shelf must be close to an elder, because a child's hand cannot reach a shelf; and that of an elder won't enter a gourd
wisdom: No one can do it all; we do need one another; cooperate and collaborate more.
scenarios: Emeka’s tall son reached a high shelf for an elder. Their teamwork solved the issue, proving mutual need. Collaboration bridged gaps.;Kemi’s small hands cleaned a tight jar for her aunt. They worked together, showing interdependence.;Tolu lifted heavy boxes for a young neighbor. Their partnership highlighted shared reliance.

proverb: Gbogbo ìgbẹ́ kọ́ lọdẹ ti ńpa ọ̀yà; gbogbo ogun kọ́ lakíkanjú ti ńyege
translation: It's not from all forests that a hunter kills a grasscutter; it's not all battles that a warrior wins
wisdom: You needn't win all battles to win the war: just win the right ones; pick your battles, wisely: don't get embroiled in trivialities.
scenarios: Chidi hunted daily but missed some game. He won key catches, proving selective wins matter. Picking battles saved energy.;Aisha fought every client dispute, exhausting herself. She settled key ones, preserving strength.;Tolu argued all points in a deal, losing it. He focused on critical terms, closing successfully.

proverb: Ìhòhò dodo làgbàdo ńwọ ilẹ̀; tó bá jáde tán ló ńdi onígba aṣọ
translation: The maize seed goes into the soil absolutely naked; it ends up with multiple peelings only after sprouting
wisdom: The best is yet to come; keep hope alive.
scenarios: Funmi’s small farm yielded big crops over time. Her patience turned bare soil into wealth. Hope brought better days.;Jide’s tiny shop grew into a chain. His persistence showed the best comes later.;Aisha’s weak voice strengthened with practice. Her growth proved brighter times ahead.

proverb: Ká panupọ̀ lé ẹlẹ́yọ́rọ́ lọ ná, kí a tó wá fàbọ̀ sí adìyẹ
translation: We ought to come together to chase away the fox first, before reverting to the hen
wisdom: Handle the most pressing of two problems first rather than inefficiently attempt the two at once.
scenarios: Kemi chased a thief before securing her goods, losing both. She prioritized her shop first, saving stock. Tackling urgent issues worked.;Tolu fought a rival while neglecting sales, failing. He focused on revenue, outpacing foes.;Chidi argued with a tenant, ignoring repairs. He fixed issues first, resolving conflicts.

proverb: Kì í rẹ ológbò, kó má lè ṣe ọdẹ eku
translation: A cat is never too tired to hunt mice
wisdom: Be steadfast, be persistent, be resilient; never quit: quitting is the only way to fail.
scenarios: Aisha’s cat chased rats despite long days. Her persistence caught pests, showing resilience wins. Steadfastness cleared problems.;Jide’s guard dog tracked intruders tirelessly. Its grit protected his shop, proving perseverance pays.;Tolu’s hen hunted bugs daily, feeding her chicks. Her diligence showed quitting fails.

proverb: Mọ̀jà mọ̀sá l'akínkanjú; akínkanjú tó bá mọ̀ọ́ jà tí kò mọ̀ọ́ sá á bá ogun lọ
translation: A good warrior must know when to fight and when to retreat; a warrior who knows when to fight but not when to retreat will die in battle
wisdom: Timing is crucial; know when to pursue, defer or quit.
scenarios: Emeka fought a losing deal, wasting funds. He pulled back, saving his firm, proving timing matters. Knowing when to quit saved him.;Kemi pushed a bad project, failing. She paused, succeeding later with better timing.;Tolu argued in a feud, escalating it. He retreated, resolving it with wise timing.

proverb: Ẹni tí bíńtí ò tó, púpọ̀ yóò jìnnà sí i
translation: Abundance will be far from whoever is not contented with a little
wisdom: Contentment is it; it makes for increase.
scenarios: Chidi chased wealth, ignoring small gains, staying broke. He valued little, growing savings. Contentment built abundance.;Aisha sought big sales, scorning small ones. She took all orders, boosting profits with gratitude.;Tolu rejected low pay, jobless for months. He accepted it, earning more later.

proverb: Tí ẹṣin bá dá'ni, a máa ńtun ùn gùn ni
translation: If one is thrown by a horse, one ought to remount it again
wisdom: If you try and fail, try again; it's not how many times you fall that counts, but how many times you get up: if you won't give up, you will win, eventually.
scenarios: Funmi fell in a race but ran again, winning. Her retries triumphed, proving persistence wins. Getting up beat failure.;Jide failed a test but studied, passing. His effort succeeded, showing resilience pays.;Tolu’s shop closed but he reopened, thriving. His comeback proved trying again works.

proverb: A kì í ṣe fáàrí ẹ̀ṣẹ́ dídì, si ọmọ adẹ́tẹ̀
translation: Do not brag about fists in the presence of a leper
wisdom: Don't show off: be considerate, courteous and tactful.
scenarios: Kemi bragged about her skills to a struggling peer, hurting them. Her tactless show offended, teaching sensitivity. She encouraged gently after.;Aisha mocked a slow learner, losing their trust. She apologized, mentoring with care.;Chidi flaunted wealth to a poor friend, straining ties. He shared humbly, rebuilding bonds.

proverb: Ìgbà ìpọ́njú là ńm'ọ̀rẹ́; ọjọ́ tó bá burú la ńm'ẹni tó fẹ́'ni
translation: It is during difficult times that true friends are known; when things are really tough is when those who truly care can be identified
wisdom: Difficult times can be useful: they help identify those who truly care
scenarios: Tolu lost clients during a slump but kept true friends. Their support rebuilt his business, showing tough times reveal allies. Loyalty shone in crisis.;Aisha’s family stood by her in debt, unlike others. Their care helped her recover, proving hardship shows love.;Kemi’s true mentor emerged during a layoff. Their guidance proved real care in bad times.

proverb: Tó bá kù díẹ̀ kí ọmọ olóore jìn sí kòtò, mànàmáná á ṣiṣẹ́ ìmọ́lẹ̀ fún un
translation: Just before a kind person would stumble into a ditch (in darkness), the lightning would light up his or her path to save the day
wisdom: Kindness pays: it's good to be good; kind acts are never lost.
scenarios: Jide helped a struggling vendor, who later referred clients. His kindness returned, proving good acts endure. Generosity paid off.;Sade fed a homeless man, who helped her shop later. Her deed came back, showing kindness lasts.;Tolu tutored a kid, whose family supported his business. His aid returned, valuing good acts.

proverb: Àìdúpẹ́ oore àná a máa mú oore sú'ni í ṣe
translation: Lack of gratitude for yesterday's kindness makes future acts of kindness tiresome
wisdom: Attitude of gratitude is it; ingratitude inhibits kindness.
scenarios: Funmi ignored her friend’s small help, losing future aid. She thanked her later, regaining support. Gratitude sustained kindness.;Aisha took her cousin’s rides for granted, and they stopped. She showed thanks, restoring favors.;Chidi dismissed his mentor’s tips, missing growth. He appreciated them, unlocking opportunities.

proverb: Ẹní bá da omi sí'wájú, á tẹ ilẹ̀ tútù
translation: Whoever waters the ground ahead, will get to step on a wet ground
wisdom: One good turn always beckons on another; sowers harvest; givers receive; seek opportunities to give.
scenarios: Kemi lent her neighbor tools, who returned better ones. Her giving sparked returns, proving good turns multiply.;Tolu shared his crops, gaining seeds from others. His generosity grew his farm, showing giving yields.;Sade helped a colleague, who promoted her later. Her aid brought rewards, valuing sowers.

proverb: Tí a kò bá jẹun sẹ́hìn àwo, èèrà ò lè gun ibi ta ti ńjẹun
translation: If one hasn't dropped one's food, ants can't be attracted to where one is eating
wisdom: Every problem has a cause; get rid of the cause and you will eliminate the problem; there is no smoke without fire.
scenarios: Chidi left food out, drawing ants. He stored it properly, stopping pests, proving causes drive issues. Eliminating roots worked.;Aisha’s open trash attracted rats. She sealed it, clearing them, showing problems have sources.;Tolu’s loose gate invited thieves. He locked it, ending break-ins, proving causes matter.

proverb: Tí àdúrà bá gbà tán, apá aládúrà ò ní ká a
translation: When a prayer is answered, the person who prayed would be overwhelmed
wisdom: Prayers work; God's response is always so complete as to need no addition.#Yoruba#proverb
scenarios: Emeka’s prayer for peace calmed a family feud. The resolution amazed him, showing prayers work. Faith delivered fully.;Aisha prayed for sales, gaining loyal clients. The abundance stunned her, proving divine answers.;Sade sought strength in prayer, lifting her spirit. Its fullness overwhelmed her, valuing faith.

proverb: Ìdọ̀bálẹ̀ kì í ṣè'wà; ohun t'ólúkálùkù máa jẹ ló ńwá
translation: Prostrating does not necessarily connote good manners; people are simply after what they can get
wisdom: Excessive genuflection or servility, is often nothing, but an attempt at sycophancy; appearance can be deceptive.
scenarios: Kemi bowed to a rude boss, seeking favors. Her act was seen as fake, losing respect. Sincerity trumped sycophancy.;Tolu flattered a client excessively, seeming insincere. His honesty later won trust, showing appearance deceives.;Chidi groveled for a deal, looking desperate. His confidence later closed it, proving humility over servility.

proverb: Ọmọ aráyé ri'ni ni wọ́n ńpe'ni; tí wọ́n ò bá rí'ni, wọ́n á pe ọmọ ẹlòmíràn
translation: You are available is why the world beckons on you; else, they'll beckon on someone else
wisdom: Humility is it; no one is indispensable.
scenarios: Funmi took her job for granted, assuming it was hers. A layoff showed others could replace her, teaching humility. She worked harder.;Aisha relied on her role’s stability, but cuts came. She stayed modest, proving no one’s vital.;Tolu thought his shop was unique, but rivals grew. He innovated, learning he wasn’t irreplaceable.

proverb: Tí ọdẹ bá ro ìṣẹ́, tó bá ro ìyà, tó bá pa ẹran, kò ní fún ẹnìkan jẹ
translation: If a hunter were to consider the hardship of his (hunting) expedition, he won't share his games with anyone
wisdom: Any kind of giving is tough (and quite often sacrificial); be appreciative.
scenarios: Jide hunted alone, sharing no meat, exhausting himself. He gave some, gaining helpers, showing giving’s value. Appreciation eased his load.;Sade cooked for one, wasting effort. She shared meals, earning gratitude, proving giving’s sacrifice pays.;Kemi hoarded resources, slowing her team. She shared, speeding work, valuing generous acts.

proverb: Adániwáyé ò gbàgbé ẹnìkan; àìmàsìkò ló ńdààmú ẹ̀dá
translation: God, the Creator, hasn't forgotten anyone; ignorance of divine timing is what makes us fret
wisdom: The best is yet to come; keep hope alive.
scenarios: Emeka fretted over delayed funds, but they came. His patience proved divine timing works. Hope eased his worry.;Aisha waited for a loan, stressed but patient. It arrived perfectly, showing God’s plan prevails.;Tolu doubted his jobless phase, but a role came. Trusting timing kept him hopeful.

proverb: Akàn etí odò, kò tí ì jìnnà sí'lé
translation: The crab on the bank of the river is not far gone from home yet
wisdom: If you are in a hole, stop digging; don't double down on stupidity; it's never too late to do the right thing.
scenarios: Chidi strayed into a risky deal, nearly trapped. He backed out, saving funds, proving retreat is wise. Stopping early worked.;Aisha joined a bad investment, losing little. She quit, avoiding worse, showing it’s never too late.;Tolu argued a lost cause, wasting time. He stopped, refocusing, proving correction saves.

proverb: Kiní yì í, kiní i wa ni, ó yàtọ̀ sí kiní yì í, kiní ì mi ni
translation: This item is ours is different from this item is mine
wisdom: If it is not wholly yours, you cannot have absolute claim on it; group ownership is grossly  limitting.
scenarios: Kemi shared team gear, claiming full credit. Her partial rights limited her, teaching group limits. Fairness clarified ownership.;Jide took group funds, acting solo. He lost trust, seeing shared claims restrict.;Sade used shared tools, overstepping. Rules curbed her, proving collective ownership binds.

proverb: Ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ kọ́ l'onísẹ́, à fi ẹni tó bá fi orí tì í  d'ópin
translation: To start anything is not as crucial as seeing it through to completion
wisdom: 'Finishiative' is superior to initiative: don't start what you won't finish; finish whatever you start.
scenarios: Tolu started a blog but quit halfway, losing readers. He relaunched, finishing strong, proving completion matters. Finishing trumped starting.;Aisha began a shop but paused, failing. She completed it, succeeding, valuing follow-through.;Kemi dropped a course, regretting it. She finished another, earning a degree, showing persistence wins.

proverb: Agbọ́n sẹ́, oyin sẹ́, ojú olóko rè é gòdògbò godogbo
translation: The wasp denies (stinging the farmer), the bee denies, yet the farmer's face remains heavily swollen
wisdom: What we say pales to what we do: our actions define and expose who we really are;  be true in fact and in appearance.
scenarios: Jide denied overcharging a client, but evidence showed it. His actions exposed him, proving deeds outweigh words. Truth defined him.;Sade hid a mistake, but it surfaced, costing trust. Her behavior revealed her, showing actions speak.;Tolu lied about sales, but records proved it. His deeds showed his true self, valuing honesty.

proverb: Ẹyìn tí yóò di epo, yóò tọ́ iná wò
translation: A palm nut that desires to become palm oil will have a taste of fire
wisdom: There's always a price tag; good things do not always come easy; no pain, no gain.
scenarios: Kemi worked overtime for a raise, earning it. Her effort paid off, proving pain brings gain. Hard work delivered.;Aisha trained for a marathon, facing soreness. She finished strong, showing no pain, no gain.;Tolu studied late, passing exams. His sacrifice succeeded, proving effort yields rewards.

proverb: Bí ọkọ̀ kan ó re Ejínrín, ẹgbẹgbẹ̀rún ẹ̀ á lọ
translation: If one bus won't go to Ejinrin town, thousands others will go
wisdom: No one, and nothing is irreplaceable; alternatives always exist, if we look well enough.
scenarios: Chidi missed a client, but others called. He found new deals, proving alternatives exist. Looking beyond loss worked.;Aisha’s supplier quit, but others stepped up. She secured stock, showing nothing’s irreplaceable.;Tolu’s partner left, but new ones joined. He thrived, proving options always exist.

proverb: Híhó ọṣẹ la fi í bọ̀wọ̀ fún un; ọ̀ṣẹ tí ò hó ò ní'yì mọ́
translation: To lather is the beauty of soap; any soap that won't lather has no honour
wisdom: Develop and hone your talent and uniqueness, and be a blessing with them; and your honour beckons.
scenarios: Tunde neglected his coding skills, sticking to outdated methods. Clients chose others, and he lost contracts. Honing his talent later won him respect.;Amaka ignored her baking gift, working a desk job. She refined her recipes, opening a successful bakery, earning honor.;Chidi let his public speaking lapse, losing audiences. Practicing daily restored his influence, proving talent brings value.

proverb: Báa gún iyán, táa ro ọkà fún kòfẹ́kògbà, kò ní fẹ́, kò ní gbà, náà ni
translation: Even if you pound yam and prepare yam flour meal for a contentious person, he or she will yet remain contentious
wisdom: Be forward-looking, be positive; do your best and keep moving.
scenarios: Kemi tried pleasing a rude client with extra work, but he complained. She delivered quality and moved on, staying positive. Her focus kept her productive.;Jide cooked for a picky neighbor, who criticized it. He stayed kind but sought better clients, ignoring negativity.;Sade met a demanding boss’s requests, yet faced complaints. She did her best, then aimed for new opportunities.

proverb: Àjọjẹ ò dùn bí ẹnìkan ò bá ní; ọjọ́ a ní la ńṣe àjọjẹ
translation: Sharing a meal isn't pleasant when one party persistently lacks; we are usually happy to share, when we all can give
wisdom: It's good to give to others, but better to empower them to help themselves.
scenarios: Funmi gave food to a struggling friend endlessly, draining herself. She taught him to cook, empowering him to thrive. Enabling self-help felt better.;Tolu lent money to his cousin repeatedly, creating dependency. He funded a small business for her, fostering independence.;Aisha shared resources with her team, but taught skills too. Their growth made sharing joyful.

proverb: Ohun tí a bá fi sílẹ̀ lẹnu ewúrẹ́ ńtó
translation: What is left unattended, is what the goat's mouth can get to
wisdom: Ultimately, we lose whatever we neglect: care for what you value.
scenarios: Chidi left his tools out, and they were stolen. He locked them up after, valuing care. Neglect cost him dearly.;Kemi ignored her garden, and weeds overtook it. She tended it daily, saving crops, learning to nurture what matters.;Tolu skipped car maintenance, facing breakdowns. Regular checks saved it, showing care prevents loss.

proverb: Ọ̀rọ̀ tó máa di akàn, bí ẹja ni í kọ́kọ́ máa ńrí
translation: What will turn out favourable eventually, often starts out with much challenges
wisdom: Don't quit; keep hope alive; if you won't give up, you will win, eventually.
scenarios: Emeka’s startup struggled early with funding issues. He persisted, and it grew profitable, proving tough starts can win. Hope kept him going.;Aisha’s shop faced slow sales at first, discouraging her. Steady effort brought loyal customers, showing persistence pays.;Jide’s novel was rejected initially, but he revised it. A publisher accepted it, rewarding his endurance.

proverb: Oko dùn ún ro l'àgbẹ̀dẹ ṣe ńrọ ọkọ́
translation: If farming were that fantastic, would blacksmiths opt to make hoes (for others)?
wisdom: Look beyond the surface: think critically; don't be naive or simplistic; things are often not quite as they appear.
scenarios: Tunde envied farmers’ profits, ignoring their toil. He tried farming, facing harsh labor, and respected their grind. proverb: Ẹni tó ńbẹ̀rù àti ṣubú, àti dìde á nira fún un
translation: Whoever is scared of falling will find rising pretty tough

proverb: A kì í wo ago aláago ṣiṣẹ́
translation: Don't carry out your duties using someone else's time piece

He set his own pace, improving fitness, valuing his path.;Sade copied her colleague’s style, losing authenticity. She embraced her own, earning respect.

proverb: Òkun kì í hó ruru, kí á wà á ruru
translation: Never paddle wildly in a stormy sea
wisdom: Be patient; complex issues must be calmly handled: cooler heads must always prevail.

proverb: Kò sí bí imú ṣe lè tóbi tó, kó lè gba ọ̀rọ̀ ẹnu sọ
translation: No matter how big the nose is, it can't take over the speaking role of the mouth

Her original work sold better, valuing uniqueness.

proverb: Òkò tí a bá bínú jù, kì í pa ẹyẹ
translation: A bird is seldom killed by a stone thrown in anger
wisdom: Actions taken in anger seldom achieve desired results; tone down the fury: it can be self-defeating.

proverb: Mọ̀jà mọ̀sá ni ti akínkanjú; akínkanjú tó bá mọ̀ọ́ jà tí kò mọ̀ọ́ sá á bá ogun lọ
translation: Warriors must know when to fight and when to retreat; a warrior who knows when to fight, but not when to retreat will perish in battle
wisdom: Know when to pursue, defer or quit.
scenarios: Emeka pushed a failing deal, losing funds. He pulled back, saving his firm, proving timing matters. Knowing when to quit saved him.;Aisha fought a bad project, failing. proverb: A kì í mọ orúkọ Ọlọ́run, kí ìyà ó jẹ'ni
translation: One cannot really know God's name (or know God for sure) and suffer

His belief brought relief, showing God’s dependability.;Kemi sought divine help in debt, finding aid. Her faith proved God’s presence.

translation: The person who hung his drum on his elbow still had the drum beaten by others, not to mention someone who hung his on a tree (branch) and walked away

She acted fast later, catching sales, valuing urgency.;Chidi ignored a job offer, losing it. He applied quickly next time, securing work.

proverb: Orí bíbẹ́ kọ́ ni oògùn orí fífọ́
translation: Decapitation is not the antidote for headache

scenarios: Kemi fired a worker harshly for a small error. The loss hurt her team, teaching moderation. She coached gently after.;Tolu banned a friend over a minor feud, regretting it. proverb: Ohun tó ṣe igúnnugún tó fi pá lórí, tó ṣe àkàlàmàgbò tó fi yọ gẹ̀gẹ̀ lọ́rùn, tó bá ṣe àgbò bọ̀lọ̀jọ̀, á ti fa ìwo rẹ̀ tu
translation: If what balded the vulture and gave the crow goiter had befallen the full-grown ram, it would have lost its horns

She adapted, valuing diverse needs.

proverb: Òròmọadìyẹ ńbá àṣá ṣeré, ó rò pé ẹyẹ oko lásán ni
translation: The chick gullibly plays with the hawk believing it to be an ordinary bird
wisdom: Naivety can be risky, if not fatally costly; invest in knowledge.

She vetted allies, learning perception’s value.;Chidi joined a risky group, facing trouble. He grew cautious, proving naivety’s cost.

proverb: Ẹni a fẹ́ la mọ̀, a ò mọ ẹni tó fẹ́'ni
translation: You do know who you love for sure, but you cannot be certain of who really loves you
wisdom: Be perceptive; things are often not as they appear.
scenarios: Sade trusted her charming boss, who ignored her work. His actions showed disinterest, teaching her to watch closely. Perception clarified truth.;Jide lent money to a friend’s sweet talk, unreturned. He checked actions, seeing true intent.;Tolu admired a mentor’s gifts, missing their neglect. He valued deeds, learning appearances deceive.

proverb: Ẹnu ẹyẹ ni í pẹyẹ; ẹnu òrofó ni í pa òrofó; òrofó bímọ mẹ́fà, ó ní ilé òun kún ṣọ́ṣọ́
translation: The mouth of a bird is its undoing; the wild pidgeon hatches just six chicks and brags that its nest is completely filled up

proverb: Ìrèké ò ní ibùdó; ibi gbogbo ló gba alágbára
translation: Sugarcane has no specific place of refuge; every situation suits a diligent fellow just fine

scenarios: Tolu worked tirelessly, opening a shop anywhere. His diligence thrived in tough markets, proving effort pays. Hard work brought success.;Kemi sold crafts in any season, outpacing rivals. Her persistence won clients, showing diligence’s reward.;Jide taught extra classes, earning more. His grit succeeded, valuing steady effort.

proverb: Ajá tó máa sọnù kì í gbọ́ fèrè ọlọ́dẹ
translation: A dog destined to get lost won't hear the hunter's (redeeming) whistling
wisdom: Those bent on a course of action won't heed wiser counsels; keep an open mind: there is some sense in nonsense.

proverb: Ibi kan ṣoṣo kọ́ la ti ńrí ọ̀run
translation: The sky is not seen from only one single spot
wisdom: Alternative approaches exist; there are many ways to achieve a goal: don't be fixated on one.

proverb: Ẹni tí kò tíì kúrò láyé, kò lè mọ irú ẹni tí òun yó dà
translation: Whoever still has life, cannot be limited in what he or she can become

proverb: A kì í ní k'ọ́mọ ẹni má d'ẹ́tẹ̀, tó bá ti lè dá'gbó gbé
translation: You never restrain your child from becoming leprous, as long as he can live in the forest alone
wisdom: Everyone bears the consequences of his or her choices.

proverb: Ìwà ọ̀lẹ ló ńba ọ̀lẹ lẹ́rù; ọ̀lẹ ṣe tán, ó ní wọn ò fẹ́ràn òun
translation: An indolent is preceded by his character but at the end complains that he or she is not accepted
wisdom: Our character often confronts us with unpleasant consequences; change your character to change any unwanted outcome.

She became kind, regaining trust, proving character shapes outcomes.;Jide’s rudeness turned off partners, hurting deals. He softened, succeeding, valuing character’s impact.

proverb: A kì í bínú sí ẹni tí a kò rí
translation: Do not be angry with someone you have not heard out
wisdom: Never rush to judgment; there is always a chance you could be wrong; always give people the benefit of the doubt.

proverb: Ọwọ‌ ata ò ṣe é fi bọ‌jú; ọwọ‌ epo ò ṣe é fi mú àlà
translation: A hand with pepper cannot be used to wash the face; the one with palm oil cannot be used to handle a white cloth
wisdom: Even with the best of intentions, some things are just inappropriate.

She washed hands, learning intent needs care.;Jide handled papers with wet hands, ruining them. He dried them, proving some acts are unfit.

proverb: Àìmọṣẹ́ kọ̀ ọmọ ajá, lọdẹ fi ńrán an níṣẹ́ ikú
translation: Not knowing how to say no, is why the dog gets sent on life-threatening errands by the hunter
wisdom: Learn to say “No”; it is not every offer that one accedes to.

proverb: Àkùrọ‌ ti lómi tẹ‌lẹ‌, kí òjò tó rọ̀  sí i

proverb: Tí àdúrà bá gbà tán, apá aládúrà ò ní ká a

proverb: Ogún ọmọdé ò lè ṣeré fún ogún ọdún; ọgbọ̀n àgbà ò lè ṣe àṣàrò fún ọgbọ̀n oṣù

proverb: Ààrò kì í gbóná títí kó máà tutù

scenarios: Chidi’s feud cooled after years, ending naturally. He moved on, proving nothing lasts. Change brought peace.;Aisha’s rival closed shop, ending competition. She focused forward, seeing endings come.;Tolu’s job ended, but a new one came. He accepted change, knowing all things pass.

proverb: Kí a fi gègé gún ara ẹni wò, kí a tó fi gún ọmọ ẹyẹ
translation: Prick yourself with the (sharp) penpoint first, before trying it on a bird

translation: Only those who would deride the elephant would claim they saw it in a jiffy; its presence is unmistakable
wisdom: Give credit where credit is due; deride no one.

proverb: Ẹni tó ńbẹ Ọlọ́run kì í bẹ èyàn

Recovery came, showing God’s dependability.;Kemi sought God’s help in debt, finding aid. Her trust proved divine care prevails.

proverb: Adániwáyè ò gbàgbé ẹnìkan; àìmàsìkò ló ńdààmú ẹ̀dá

proverb: Ibi tí à ńlọ là ńwò, a kì í wo ibi tí a ti ṣubú
